title: 106_hr2905
content: The Act may be cited as the "Integrity in Banking and Money Laundering Prevention Act of 1999". The Congress finds that money laundering is a serious problem, with billions of dollars being laundered annually. This activity supports illicit trades like drug trafficking, terrorism, and arms smuggling, allowing criminals to hide their profits and undermine financial institutions. Money laundering by international criminal enterprises poses a threat to national governments, corrupts institutions, and violates legal norms and human rights. US financial institutions play a crucial role in combating money laundering, with private banking services estimated to have assets worth billions of dollars. The Act aims to combat money laundering by extending legislation to all financial institutions, including securities brokers. It prioritizes combating money laundering in US financial institutions, closing gaps in the private banking system, targeting high-intensity money laundering areas, and reporting on private banking activities. To prevent abuse in private banking, US financial institutions must maintain documentation of offshore accounts and subject securities brokers to suspicious activities reporting requirements. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this Act, definitions include "beneficial owner" as a person or group controlling an account at a financial institution, "concentration account" as a business account where funds are commingled, "financial institution" as defined in title 31, and "high net worth individual" as someone with a significant net worth. A high net worth individual is defined as someone whose joint net worth with their spouse exceeds $1,000,000, or who had individual gross income over $400,000 in each of the 2 preceding calendar years, or joint gross income over $600,000 in each of the 2 preceding calendar years and expects to exceed that amount in the current year. Money laundering is defined as concealing the existence, illegal source, or illegal use of income. Private banking involves the personal delivery of financial products and services to high net worth individuals, including various services like deposits, lending, investing, trust administration, and fund transfers. It is a way to disguise illegal income to make it appear legitimate. Private banking activities are to be reported on according to Section 4. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with relevant agencies, must submit a report on private banking activities in the U.S. within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. The report should cover the nature and extent of private banking, regulatory efforts to monitor compliance with relevant laws. Financial institutions must have policies and procedures in place to ensure compliance with specific laws and regulations. SEC. 5 amends Section 5318(h) of title 31 to require financial institutions to maintain concentration accounts properly to prevent money laundering. The Secretary of the Treasury will prescribe regulations for account information. SEC. 6 involves designating foreign high-intensity money laundering areas. SEC. 6 involves the designation of foreign high-intensity money laundering areas under Subchapter III of chapter 53 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant authorities, will develop criteria to identify foreign areas with concentrated money laundering activities. Any foreign country meeting these criteria will be designated as a high-intensity money laundering area, with financial institutions receiving written notice and warning. The Secretary will identify foreign areas with concentrated money laundering activities and designate them as high-intensity money laundering areas. Financial institutions will receive a written warning about the money laundering concentration in those countries. SEC. 7. Double the criminal penalties for violations involving high-intensity money laundering areas. SEC. 8. Enhanced ability to identify the beneficial owner of offshore accounts. The court may double the sentence of fine or imprisonment for violations involving high-intensity money laundering areas. Effective date applies to violations committed after the enactment of this Act. Section 5318 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to require domestic financial institutions to keep records of beneficial owners of accounts outside the US for law enforcement tracing of funds. Domestic financial institutions must keep records of beneficial owners of accounts outside the US for law enforcement tracing of funds. The records should include participant information, legal capacity, and real parties involved in transactions. The curr_chunk states the requirement for disclosing the identity of the real parties in interest in transactions. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Securities and Exchange Commission, must establish regulations within one year for brokers and dealers to report suspicious transactions relevant to potential violations of law or regulation.
